chapter.title: Installation
chapter.para: FLOW3 is based on the newest technologies of tomorrow like for example namespaces. These technologies aren't available in the stable PHP 5.2 releases at the moment, but are implemented in PHP 5.3. It has no final release until now, so operating system distributors do not provide PHP 5.3 packages. You can find instructions to install the newest release candidate of PHP 5.3 for widely used operating systems in the appendixes.

section.title: Requirements
section.para: The following minimum requirements are operating system independent. Developers told about working instances on Debian Linux, MacOS, Windows XP and Windows Vista.

listitem.para: PHP 5.3 RC2 or newer (but not PHP 6)

section.para: (Other webservers (f.e. IIS) could work, but have not been tested until now)
We have written installation instructions for PHP 5.3 that might be helpful for you.

section.title: Installion of FLOW3
section.para: These steps require the server requirements to be set up. Instruction on how to do that can be found in the appendixes.

step.para: Download the FLOW3 distribution from http://flow3.typo3.org/download/

Unzip / un-phar it to the document root of the webserver (often "htdocs")
It is highly recommended to change the document root of the webserver to the Public subfolder of the FLOW3 distribution!

The webserver needs write permissions for some subfolders. The FLOW3 distribution provides a helper script for Unix like operating systems, which sets the permissions. Change to the top level folder of the FLOW3 distribution, there you will find the script setfilepermissions.sh. Execute this script providing the webserver user and group as parameters. On Debian Linux (Lenny) the commando would look like this:

section.para: Now you can check if FLOW3 works by pointing your browser to http://<hostname>/ . If everything works you should see the Welcome screen of the FLOW3 distribution (this may take some time on the first call, because FLOW3 needs to initialize itself and to create caching data): The FLOW3 welcome screen

tip.para: On Windows systems PHP causes problems with long filenames. To avoid errors you should change the configuration of the cache to a place that leads to a very short absolute filepath, for example C:\t\ or C:\t\x\ (if you want to install more than one instance of FLOW3). Do that by adding the following lines to the file Configuration/FLOW3.yaml in your FLOW3-Distribution (the indenting must be done with two spaces):utility: environment: temporaryDirectoryBase: C:/t/x/
If (on Windows) you see the XAMPP default page after calling the FLOW3 URI, you might have forgotten to add the port number.

note.para: The persistence framework / content repository stores its data in an already set up sqlite database by default. It can be changed to a real database like for example MySQL. This requires some configuration which will be covered here later.

section.title: Setup Eclipse PDT for PHP 5.3
section.para: PHP 5.3 introduced the support of namespaces. This is a completly new syntax in PHP which is not supported by most editors (yet). Even the stable version of Eclipse PDT doesn't support namespaces syntax. So you have to install some Release Candidate of PDT 2.1, if you don't want to see all those red syntax-error-symbols in your php-files.
